text: the internet boom in the last two to three years has sent information technology it companies tripping over each other to spot the next money-making trend and they seem to have zeroed in on the same idea -- business transactions over the net `` electronic commerce '' and `` e-business '' are the latest buzzwords at leading it companies including ibm corp and digital equipment corp where engineers are trying to come up with an array of choices for people and companies to buy and sell in cyberspace at the internet world international conference held in singapore in late january speeches workshops exhibitions and meetings with the media centred on the promise of electronic commerce the push factors while the debate rages on over just how useful and profitable electronic commerce can be it companies are not waiting for the dust to settle `` the technology is n't perfect but the business incentive is so compelling it 's worth the risk the biggest risk is to do nothing '' rose ann giordano digital 's vice president internet business group said in her keynote address the expectation that a huge number of people will be surfing the net is pushing companies in that direction `` close to 40 million people are expected on-line by year 's end '' said john patrick ibm 's vice president of internet technology `` how will businesses take advantage of the ability to reach an increasing number of people around the world via the internet and intranets `` e-business is what will change the economies of the world it will allow businesses to reach out to touch constituencies they could n't before '' he said ibm has identified three areas in e-business -- ways to conduct commerce business collaboration and managing content on the internet question on profit and usefulness analysts say the stage is set for electronic commerce but it may not prove to be immediately profitable for businesses operating in cyberspace `` i see the basic infrastructure for this business is already there but i do n't see it being profitable so soon '' said patrick yau technology analyst at schroders securities ibm launched its virtual shopping mall called world avenue in the last quarter of 1996 and now has about 15 merchants signed on it gets a start-up fee from the vendors a five percent commission on sales and a monthly maintenance charge some critics say such a retailing concept does not add much value other than the convenience of shopping from home `` malls on the internet are not what people want '' said stan dolberg a forrester research analyst in a reuter report `` if they want a mall they want products grouped together by categories say like shoes so they can comparison shop ... the internet itself is like a whole mall where a lot of different things are already grouped together '' he said other recent internet shopping mall efforts have also failed like mci communications corp 's mci marketplace while ibm conceded it was too early to tell if its virtual mall would succeed it said one advantage was that people would be able to shop as and when they liked even when shops were closed `` we are thinking of doing a poll at one of the large malls to ask if people really enjoy shopping at the mall itself '' said patrick technologies in the pipeline ibm hopes to license a project called panoramix currently being tested which gives a three-dimensional experience be it in a shop or a museum the consumer can view products close up and effect a purchase through a simple point and click digital is demonstrating millicent a technology that allows low-value transactions credit card companies normally would not accept and the network computer which the industry is banking on to help boost electronic commerce will be rolled out from the first half of this year software company oracle corp champions the network computer -- a simple and cheap device that pulls data from a network -- as the way to get computer-shy people onto the net as it would look and work like a consumer device for instance a television set security and cost companies say hurdles like security bandwidth and regulation have already been crossed or would soon be resolved the major barrier is gaining people 's trust that it is safe to do business over the net ibm and digital say that with techniques such as encryption now available it is as safe if not safer to transact over the net than over the telephone at the end of the day the lure of electronic commerce is that it provides new ways of doing business at a lower cost `` small businesses will have a global reach which they could n't have before vendors can go directly to customers and cut out the middlemen '' said giordano businesses can exist without buildings and with fewer staff resulting in lower overheads inventory levels can be cut yau of schroders said banks would probably be the first to adopt electronic commerce in a big way as they were the ones who had the financial resources to invest in the technology analysts say electronic commerce will only really take off when people find the net as comfortable as using the telephone will a parallel economy emerge in cyberspace the debate goes on

boeing co. friday appointed long-time executive richard pearson to head the commercial aircraft operations acquired in its purchase of mcdonnell douglas corp pearson who joined boeing in 1967 led the company 's commercial airplane group transition team in the seven months leading up to the 16.3 billion merger which became effective friday pearson eventually will move to california to oversee the douglas products division formerly known as douglas aircraft co. which makes the md-80 md-90 md-95 and md-11 airplanes at plants in orange county the long-term fate of those models is uncertain although boeing chairman phil condit said last week he saw potential for derivatives of the new md-95 that would be smaller than any plane the company currently offers walter orlowski who had served as president of douglas aircraft will move to seattle to become a vice president in boaing 's commercial airplane group boeing has not yet made any announcements about management of its defence and space operations which constitute the bulk of the assets acquired in the merger a company spokesman said `` no consensus '' was reached on whether the operations will be based in seattle or st. louis where fighter jets including the f-15 and f/a 18 are manufactured a reorganization also is possible alan mulally the recently appointed president of boeing 's defence and space operations is on vacation and will not take part in any of the `` day one '' celebrations planned for monday at 40 boeing sites across the country a spokesman said

a recent flip-flop in indian aviation policy barring foreign airlines from taking stakes in the domestic sector sends worrisome signals about the pace of economic reform analysts and businessmen said on sunday prime minister h.d deve gowda 's crisis-ridden cabinet on tuesday prohibited foreign airlines from taking stakes in domestic ventures though it let other foreign investors in `` this decision will send out negative signals just as the government was doing fine on other economic fronts '' said v. raghuraman secretary-general of the associated chambers of commerce and industry assocham a direct casualty of the new rule is a proposed tie-up between india 's largest business group the tatas and singapore airlines to set up a 600 million domestic network `` it 's a case of india shooting itself in the foot very few airlines can stand alone nowadays a monopoly situation causes all sorts of inefficiencies '' said graham hayward executive director of the singapore international chamber of commerce the tatas planned to take a 60 percent stake in the airline and sia the rest according to a february 1995 proposal which the government sat on for two years it became the focus of a high-profile battle by civil aviation minister c.m ibrahim to protect state-run airlines air-india which operates on international routes and indian airlines which flies domestic routes `` i think it 's very sectoral they do n't want to liberalise the airline sector for whatever reason but that does n't mean that in other sectors they wo n't do that '' said dilip ratha senior economist at w.i carr stockbrokerage in singapore he said it would not make foreign investors more cautious about india because they were already very cautious india hopes to attract 10 billion in foreign direct investment annually over the next few years mainly to improve its overburdened infrastructure to support economic growth of around seven percent a year foreign direct investment approvals totalled 26.7 billion between august 1991 and december 1996 and in the nine months april to december 1996 the figure was only marginally up on the 1.5 billion for the same period a year earlier a strategist with a foreign investment bank said there were still grounds for hope that the civil aviation ministry will drop its objections to foreign airlines entering india 's market `` if one looks at it coolly it is probably just a short-term phenomenon the result of animosity between the industry minister and the civil aviation minister '' he said indian airlines is closer to moving into the black on friday it reported a 1996/97 net loss of 407.5 million rupees against a loss of 1.09 billion 1995/96 it forecast net profit in 1997/98 at 953 million rupees the cabinet also limited foreign firms that are not airlines to 40 percent equity stakes in domestic airlines the moves have radically affected jet airways india 's largest private airline in which two foreign airlines have stakes gulf air holdings and kuwait airways each have 20 percent stakes valued at 4 million in jet airways whose fleet of 12 aircraft operates 74 flights each day to 23 destinations jet airways would divest its foreign equity an airline official told reuters `` the policy decision has been taken we will also disinvest and go by the government requirements '' he said the government has fixed a six-month deadline for divestment no other country allowed international carriers to operate its domestic services said an aviation analyst who did not want to be named `` why should india be any different '' he asked india began opening its aviation sector to private enterprise under an economic liberalisation programme launched by then prime minister p.v narasimha rao in 1991 a dozen domestic airlines quickly sprang up but were winnowed down to a handful by crippling fuel and maintenance costs low occupancy rates and government laws that force them to fly to remote unprofitable regions last year the civil aviation ministry began reviewing policies governing foreign equity stakes in domestic airlines india 's creaking infrastructure has also slowed growth in air traffic

kansas city power light co said sunday that it continues to recommend that shareholders not tender their shares to western resources inc kcpl said that unless western determines to let its exchange offer terminate it will be required to extend its offer from time to time for a `` substantial '' period of time kcpl said that western 's offer has been open since july and that since then a little more than 40 percent of the company 's shares outstanding were tendered to western earlier on sunday western resources said that more than 44 percent of kcpl shares have been tendered and that it has extended its offer deadline to novemer 15 1996

news corp ltd chief executive and chairman rupert murdoch said in a newspaper interview published on friday that news was still on track for a 20 percent increase in profit in the current 1996/97 year `` if the american economy holds where it is and the british one does yes certainly the 20 percent increase is attainable '' murdoch told news corp 's courier mail newspaper in an interview news corp said after its 1995/96 results in late august that a 20 percent profit rise was very attainable `` but it is still early days to be saying that '' the newspaper quoted murdoch as saying

dell computer corp chief financial officer tom meredith said tuesday surging demand from owners of older personal computers will boost revenues in the next two years about 135 million personal computers based on micro processors older than the top of the line pentium will be replaced and dell which is one of the favored vendors among second time personal computer buyers will benefit meredith said `` there will be a bow wave of replacements '' as customers look for machines that can handle internet access and a new generation of software he said at a montgomergy securities investment conference here on monday dell said it expects a `` strong '' third quarter based on robust worldwide personal computer sales

uk general insurance brokers will have to increase their investment in information technology to meet the competitive threat from direct telephone insurers in personal lines insurance `` general insurance brokers will be in for a tough time unless they harness technology to combat the threat from direct writers '' management consultancy datamonitor said in a report insurance brokers will spend 177 million stg on it this year rising to 199 million in 2001 datamonitor said in its report 'it in uk personal general insurance brokers will expand their use of call centres databases the internet and e-mail however by 2000 their share of personal general insurance will have fallen to 36 percent from 61 percent in 1995 it added the expansion of direct writers will lead to mergers acquisitions and some brokers withdrawing from the personal lines market for motor and household insurance brokers will have to respond to this trend by investing in direct distribution of policies over the telephone and the internet the report said -- reuters insurance news 44 171 542 2769

in a bid to draw a final curtain on the savings and loan crisis of the 1980s the house banking committee voted on thursday in favor of eliminating the federal charter for thrift institutions in a third day of debate on legislation to overhaul aging u.s. financial laws the committee rejected an amendment sponsored by rep. john lafalce democrat of new york and jack metcalf republican of washington to preserve the thrift charter provisions in the financial modernization legislation would force all thrifts to begin operating as banks although with some grandfathering of their currently authorized powers in a vote that crossed party lines the committee voted 26-23 to reject the amendment the committee then went on to consider an amendment sponsored by florida republican bill mccollum to lengthen the period under which thrifts would be allowed to operate under the grandfather provision the vote bolstered the chances for final passage of the legislation because the banking industry has said it would actively oppose the bill if the thrift charter was preserved bankers reluctantly backed the mccollum amendment `` it 's not ideal for us but we are willing to go along with it to defeat the lafalce amendment '' said ed yingling the top lobbyist for the american bankers association -- aaron pressman 202 898-8312

poland 's privatisation ministry will sign a formal agreement with its advisor in the sale of the polar sa white goods maker by the end of the month privatisation minister wieslaw kaczmarek said on thursday in august poland picked a consortium of bank handlowy w warszawie sa and a polish consortium firm access to advise in the privatisation the state-owned polar said earlier this week it planned to offer more than 70 million zlotys worth of new stock to the public and to enter the warsaw bourse in the first half of 1997 the company which makes refrigerators freezers and washing machines said it would not seek a strategic investor in the near future but did not rule out an alliance with another renowned producer later -- warsaw newsroom +48 22 653 9700

the u.s. justice department said thursday it has had `` talks '' with nationwide mutual insurance co. which has been accused of discriminating against minorities in selling homeowner policies in urban neighbourhoods `` we are engaged in talks with nationwide regarding allegations of discrimination '' spokeswoman lee douglass said in a telephone interview `` the talks have been constructive '' asked if a full-scale investigation is under way she said the department does not confirm or deny any investigations columbus ohio-based nationwide the sixth largest u.s. property/casualty insurer said it was reviewing its urban marketing strategy the company plans a news conference friday `` we are evaluating whether our underwriting guidelines constitute a barrier to our gaining market share in urban markets '' nationwide spokesman john millen said in a telephone interview late thursday a non-profit organisation the national fair housing alliance said nationwide makes it difficult or costly for homeowners in predominantly african-american hispanic or integrated urban neighbourhoods to insure their homes the group had homeowners in such neighbourhoods ask insurers for information then had owners of comparable homes in mostly white suburban neighbourhoods do the same `` our investigations have shown that nationwide has engaged in discrimination in several ways '' executive director shanna smith said in a telephone interview for example an urban home might cost two to three times as much to insure as its suburban counterpart in some areas nationwide would not insure homes valued at less than 60,000 or limit coverage on homes built before 1950 she said `` that had a greater impact on integrated and minority neighbourhoods '' since many urban homes are older and valued at less than similar suburban homes she said nationwide 's millen said its age and valuation guidelines were based on traditional industry standards nationwide insurance enterprise 's property and casualty companies including nationwide mutual are separate business units from a life insurance unit nationwide financial services inc. which plans a public offering of stock

two people were killed and several others were injured when a blast rocked a station of the regional express underground railway in paris on tuesday prime minister alain juppe told reporters juppe gave no estimate of the number of people injured by the explosion which occurred around 6.30 p.m. 1730 gmt at the port royal rer station on the left bank officials said earlier that 28 people were injured `` there are apparently two dead '' juppe said before leaving his office for the scene of the blast the blast took place in a carriage of the rer train `` we heard a strong blast '' one witness who was in a bus above the station told france-info radio `` there was a column of black smoke which enveloped the bus there was a strong smell of powder like at a shooting range '' the explosion occurred on the same line and two stations away from saint-michel station where a blast in july last year killed eight people and injured nearly 100 launching a wave of attacks across france by algerian moslem fundamentalists

air france pilots drawing back from a showdown which might have forced the resignation of airline chairman christian blanc voted to delay a four-day strike scheduled to begin on sunday `` seventy percent of the pilots at the general assembly voted for a delay in the strike '' an air france spokeswoman said blanc had threatened to resign if the stoppage went ahead he had estimated the strike would cost one billion francs 175 million dashing his hopes of piloting air france to financial breakeven this year and an early privatisation the pilot 's decision was confirmed in a vote by union representatives geoffroy bouvet head of the snpl union said 21 delegates had approved a motion to delay the strike by two months seven opposed it and five abstained unions had called the strike from march 23 to 26 to protest against blanc 's plan to hire 450 younger pilots on lower wages blanc wants to cut the flight crew wage bill by 15 percent to bring it into line with its european and u.s. rivals as part of a three-year plan to boost competitiveness the company is under pressure to reduce costs with the european air travel market opening up to full competition next month air france had proposed to hire new pilots at a starting annual gross salary of 220,000 francs 38,500 compared to the start-up pay of 330,000 francs 57,800 that current pilots received when they began their careers according to french news reports the new starting wage is higher than those of lufthansa and british airways and nearly 40 percent above starting wages at american airlines snpl chief bouvet said blanc had agreed not to put the new wage scale into effect during the two-month postponement of the strike to allow discussions with the unions

fai insurances ltd expects profits to continue to grow in the future fai director and chief financial officer timothy mainprize said at a roadshow in singapore on wednesday `` our profits will continue to improve over the next few years '' mainprize told potential investors in the insurance company 's recently announced us 75 million floating rate note in february chief executive rodney adler said in a statement the company should maintain profit growth in the absence of abnormal events in the insurance field the company 's net profit for the first half ended december 31 rose by 35.4 percent to australian 7.7 million mainprize noted the company 's claims paying ability was upgraded by standard and poor 's corp last october to an investment-grade bbb-minus `` we are reasonably confident that we shall be upgraded up again '' he said he said fai was talking with a large u.s. insurer -- which he did not identify -- about the possibility of entering into an agreement to market information technology insurance

the world 's second longest suspension bridge is due to be officially opened this weekend amid concern among hong kong 's air cargo industry about the `` unthinkable '' industry sources told reuters the hk 7.1 billion eight lane double-deck road and rail bridge is the spectacular centre piece of the lantau link which includes two other bridges and viaducts it will open for traffic on may 22 it is the only land connection between the territory 's new chek lap kok airport off lantau island and the rest of hong kong industry sources fear if the link were ever cut the airport would be paralysed and hong kong 's economy immediately affected cargo sources said last year 's channel tunnel fire showed how disaster can easily strike and cause months of chaos for cargo operators security concerns at the new bridge were raised earlier this week when electrical wires were cut in 32 places already tight security has been strengthened according to officials a barge derrick crashing into a nearby bridge last year also raised safety concerns a hong kong government spokesman said the chances of the bridge ever having to close were `` very very remote '' he said it was typhoon-proof and road traffic could switch to the enclosed lower deck but said `` unforeseen things can happen '' a private company has been given the contract to ensure traffic flows smoothly along the entire tsing ma control area he added in the event of the `` worst case scenario '' with a total bridge closure the spokesman said contingency measures are being drawn up for passenger ferries to be requisitioned and replace the express rail service which will also use the bridge as yet there are no provisions for cargo handling `` if the worst comes to the worst passengers are the priority we have no contingency plan for cargo yet '' he said in an interview with hong kong handling record amounts of cargo up to 5,700 tonnes in one day it is doubtful whether any contingency measures would be able to handle just a fraction of the daily total industry sources said yeung kwok keung deputy managing director of hong kong air cargo terminals ltd which will operate the superterminal one air cargo terminal at chek lap kok said this week 's wire cutting sabotage had been helpful in raising security concerns `` it does not bear thinking about that the airport operation will be reliant on anything other than the bridge link if in the unlikely unwelcome and unfortunate event of the link being cut off and with the sea-based contingency plan in operation i have no doubt whatsoever that the impact on flight movements will be very significant '' yeung told reuters with thousands of consignments being handled every day the terminal would quickly clog up with incoming cargo and run out of storage space aircraft bound for hong kong would then have to be turned away and departing flights could leave empty yeung said `` the cargo industry has to look at and consider the likely impact on their trade of such a long cut off and it is something which we will be looking at it is a general concern but we are not terrified as yet at the prospect of such a disconnection because we do believe that the possibility is low to the extreme '' yeung added an airline operators committee source which represents all airlines airport managers and ground handling managers said he is also concerned `` i believe the issue is so important not just for airlines air freight forwarders but for the hong kong economy as a whole that some contingency measures should be drawn up '' he added at 1,377 metres long it is the world 's second longest suspension bridge after the humber bridge in england according to the new airport projects coordination office former british prime minister lady thatcher will officiate at this week 's opening ceremony

transaction charges for trading gas on the uk spot market may rise from 1.50 stg to 2.75 stg under a plan put forward at a meeting of the claims validation agency which confirms that gas has actually been delivered after a transaction new general manager of claims validation services ltd charles mason-smith said that at a meeting on monday approval was given to seek member 's agreement to raise the transaction charge by this level this applies for each transaction so that if a company transacts for example 25,000 therms a day of gas for a month of 31 days then the transaction charge is payable 31 times mason-smith said he could not be sure when the new charge may start to apply otherwise he said the meeting renewed director 's contracts and discussed `` some general bits of business '' -- sebastian alison london newsroom +44 171 542 6412

british pop superstars oasis rocked by rumours of a split told anxious fans on tuesday they would release a new album next year after abruptly pulling out of a concert tour of the united states last week the million-selling band said it would start work on their long-awaited third album next month when their tour collapsed amid reports that singer liam gallagher and his guitarist brother noel had come to blows their record company denied reports oasis would split but confirmed they would not be touring for the foreseeable future the oasis story caused a furore in the british media obsessed with the most popular british band since the beatles split up in 1970 liam once boasted `` we are bigger than jesus we will be as big as the beatles if not bigger '' in their latest statement oasis denied reports of internal differences disappointing ticket sales in the u.s. and suggestions that liam 's girlfriend was breaking up the band `` the reason for the premature return of the band has nothing to do with recent uk tabloid hysteria eg poor ticket sales liam 's fiancee patsy kensit sibling rivalry or internal differences '' the statement said `` it was a decision taken solely by noel gallagher on behalf of his four friends we look forward to presenting our fans with a new album in the summer of '97 '' oasis whose first two albums have sold 20 million copies have led a `` britpop '' revival a summer concert drew a record crowd of 250,000 but the feuding between the gallagher brothers has generated as many headlines as the music oasis 's record company creation is 49 percent owned by sony music

the future of a popular tourist spot -- the bureau of engraving and printing plant near the mall -- as well as vast potential cost savings are at stake in the fight over a new u.s. 1 coin `` eliminating the one-dollar note could substantially reduce and possibly eliminate the need for a washington d.c. production plant '' the general accounting office said thursday in a look at coinage and money-printing operations bill printing could be consolidated in fort worth texas if a 1 coin were issued in place of the note gao officials said they said the bureau preferred to have a back-up plant but had not decided whether to replace the washington plant the bureau of engraving and printing says 700,000 people a year visit the plant which prints bills in denominations from 1 to 100 members of a house banking subcommittee were skeptical a 1 coin would be a success given the lackluster record of the susan b. anthony dollar coin nor were some of them ready to stop producing the 1 bill a key premise in gao 's estimate that the 1 coin would save 456 million a year in costs coins can last 30 years but paper notes must be replaced every 16 months at government expense `` these are not false savings '' said michael motley gao associate director for government business operations who said other nations successfully converted to coins `` well fine you run on that platform '' retorted rep. joe kennedy a massachusetts democrat public acceptance of a 1 coin could rise motley said if it had a distinctive color or if a new design was adopted the anthony coin honoring the women 's sufferage leader was faulted as too similar in size and appearance to the 25-cent coin the u.s. mint no longer produces the anthony dollar but has a three-year supply stockpiled it estimates it would take 30 months to develop and begin production of a new 1 coin if congress ordered it gao said the mint could resume production of the anthony dollar if supplies ran out and a new 1 coin was not ordered but rep. floyd flake new york democrat said paper notes were lighter and easier to carry than 1 coins he was not mollified by a suggestion that more 2 bills could be printed if a 1 coin was mandated `` it 's a pain in the butt to carry all those coins in your pocket '' flake said in the past five years the 1 bill accounted for 47 percent of notes produced by the bureau of engraving and printing it could cost 73 million to gear up to produce a 1 coin according to the mint a new bill-printing plant could cost from 158 million to 250 million

riscorp inc said on tuesday james malone has resigned as president and chief operating officer malone 's duties will be assumed by chief executive frederick dawson who also was named president riscorp said also richard franz has resigned as senior vice president and chief financial officer and will be replaced by stephen rece senior vice president and head of the company 's reinsurance department riscorp said riscorp was not immediately available for further comment last week the company announced plans to reduce its workforce and focus its operations on the managed workers compensation insurance business the company has not yet filed its 10-k annual report for 1996 and its first quarter 10-q report with the securities and exchange commission riscorp declined to disclose a reason for the resignations tuesday 10 june 1997 20:38:39 ends nn10239403

pakistani prime minister nawaz sharif increased government support prices for wheat rice and oilseeds in a package announced on thursday aimed at boosting output he told a national farmers convention in islamabad his six-week-old government would announce more incentives for agriculture in the next few days with the aim to make pakistan self-sufficient in food for now sharif said the government 's support prices to be paid to farmers for a unit of 40 kg had been increased for wheat by nearly 30 percent to 240 rupees 5.97 from 185 rupees and by 25 percent for irri varieties of rice the support price for canola oilseed had been increased 12.5 percent to 450 rupees from 400 rupees per 40 kg and for sunflower about 17 percent to 450 rupees from 385 he said the package which includes concessions in the price of some agricultural inputs and promises of better credit follows economic reform measures announced by sharif last friday that slashed taxes and import tariffs the government says it plans to announce more measures to revamp and cut back state corporations reform banking and capital markets and promote investment thursday 's package abolished sales tax on government-certified seeds promised a cut in duties on locally made tractors and other agricultural machinery and reduced import duty on used and reconditioned harvesters to 10 percent from 35 percent sharif said he wanted to see pakistan self-sufficient in foodgrains within two years and declared fiscal 1997/98 july-june as a `` grow more wheat year '' `` is it not shameful that a country having vast fertile land area the world 's best irrigation system good weather conditions and strong and hard-working hands has to import wheat worth 25 billion rupees 622 million every year '' he asked he said pakistan was annually importing oilseeds worth 30 billion rupees lentils costing three billion rupees and also sugar after being self-sufficient in the commodity for years `` the cotton crop was a pride for us but now we are forced to import cotton as well '' he added '' food and agriculture minister abida hussain in her speech attributed pakistani agriculture 's `` bleak scenario '' to small land holdings soil erosion productivity constraints water loss transfer of resources to other sectors and shifts of population from villages to cities

from now on jenny craig inc. must warn consumers its weight loss methods are usually only temporary the federal government said thursday the provision is one of several announced by the federal trade commission settling deceptive advertising charges brought against the weight loss company in 1993 claims in most ads will have to include the statement `` for many dieters weight loss is temporary '' jenny craig will also have to disclose the average weight loss maintenance for consumers the commission said the government agency also focused on testimonials based on experiences atypical of most jenny craig clients testimonials about highly successful maintenance of weight loss must now be accompanied by the phrase `` this result is not typical you may be less successful '' in the past some ads suggested dieters could lose all the weight they wanted for 49 although the actual costs could run into hundreds of dollars jenny craig must end that practice the commission said in a statement jenny craig said `` the consent agreement does not suggest the company violated any law or regulation and it does not involve payment by the company of any financial damages '' but jenny craig faces civil penalties of up to 11,000 per day if it fails to live up to its promises ftc spokeswoman bonnie jansen said jenny craig president c. joseph labonte said `` after nearly six years of discussions we 're pleased to put this matter behind us '' but apparently the settlement could have been reached years ago ftc spokeswoman jansen noted that similar settlements were reached in 1993 with three other weight loss companies jenny craig did not settle and charges were filed while the consent agreement itself makes no comment about the company 's past practices jansen noted that it settles charges of deceptive advertising `` jenny craig has agreed not to misrepresent the performance safety or customer endorsement of any weight loss programme and to have scientific data to back up future claims '' the ftc said the ftc vote was 4-0 the public will have 60 days to comment to the ftc office of the secretary 6th and pennsylvania ave. nw washington dc 20580 the public can also reach the ftc through the world wide web at http //www.ftc.gov similar charges against weight watchers were pulled from litigation a week ago pending the possibility of a settlement with the ftc

according to the draft which is to be submitted to parliament on monday hungary plans to reduce inflation and the budget deficit and widen the base of social security contributions medgyessy told a news conference hungary plans to push average annual inflation down to 18 percent next year compared with the latest official forecast of 22 to 24 percent for 1996 the country targets a general government deficit of 390 billion forints or 4.9 percent of the gross domestic product gdp for next year which is not comparable to this year 's four percent projection as the accounting system of the state debt will change from 1997 medgyessy said `` in a comparative structure the 4.9 percent corresponds to three percent '' the minister told a conference of local municipalities on wednesday adding that the change was technical and did not demand economic policy action the planned accounting change means that the devaluation losses on hungary 's foreign state debt will appear in the state budget security budget even next year he said adding that the latest offical forecast for the 1996 social security deficit for 1996 was 53 billion forints this was up from the 17.8 billion original target gov christie whitman on wednesday outlined a spending plan for new jersey in the fiscal year starting july 1 while spending is rising only 1.3 percent the budget contains small initiatives designed to please key constituencies bond raters thought the budget appreared reasonable steven hochman assistant director of state ratings at moody 's investors service said `` the economic assumptions appear to be reasonable their revenues to date in the current fiscal year are on target '' and the revenue projections for the next fiscal year appear to be reasonable hochman said however he noted `` we have questions about the non-recurring resources '' he cited the projected benefits of the proposed pension obligation bond program and the potential for budget relief `` that is an area we will be examining more closely '' he said moody 's rates the state 's general obligation bonds aa1 robin prunty a director with standard poor 's corp said the pension financing plan `` in and of itself '' would not cause the state 's rating to be downgraded s p rates the debt aa-plus she also added `` we are comfortable with thier use of non-recurring revenues '' environmentalists were pleased that the department of environmental protection will not lose any staff positions in the 1,235 job cuts she announced curtis fisher of the new jersey public interest reasearch group said he was pleased by a pilot project to operate 50 buses fueled by natural gas child advocates were pleased by her proposed health insurance plan for children who lack coverage children first will be a private-public partnership whitman said the utility industry was pleased by her plan to end the gross receipts and franchise tax but mayors and municipal managers were wary about the impact on state aid whitman defended the sale of 3.4 billion in bonds to liquidate unfunded liabilities in four state pension plans that will enable treasurer brian clymer to divert some of 2.3 billion in surplus cash in those funds to defray parts of the state 's annual contributions total expenditures will reach 16.4 billion up from a revised fy 1997 total of 16.2 billion the budget deals some bad news to local governments and to higher education -- state aid will remain the same it also calls for shedding 1,235 jobs with an estimated 735 by layoff clymer said that if historic patterns hold up actual layoffs will be about 320 the budget relies on two controversial gimmicks to achieve a comnfortable balance one would raise 200 million by selling the state 's temporary disability insurance plan which covers 2.4 million new jerseyans with a 105 payroll tax `` private firms already provide this insurance just as efficiently '' whitman said the second maneuver would have a bigger impact it would raise 3.4 billion by the sale of bonds to liquidate the unfunded liabilities in the four pension fdunds run on behalf of state county and local employees that would free up 2.3 billion in `` surplus '' -- capital not needed to cover current obligations clymer proposes to use some of those funds to reduce the state 's cash contribution to the funds by 269 million in the current budget and 354 million in said the budget appeared to have passed the last hurdle the senate or upper house without amendments and its adoption is expected remove one problem in the central african country 's dealings with the imf and its other creditors the congo news agency quoted the government as saying increased spending was justified by a projected rise in revenues despite the persistence of deficits congo expects nkossa production which is expected to push congo 's annual oil production to 13 million tonnes this year from nine million tonnes parliament last week adopted a law for the introduction of value hizbollah attacked the lebanese government 's budget policies on thursday accusing it of proposing unrealistic spending plans to parliament and then massively exceeding them ammar moussawi one of the pro-iranian group 's seven deputies told parliament the 1997 draft budget did not reflect government financial policy because most investment spending took place outside the budget and was financed by foreign debt speaking on the second day of the annual budget debate he called the government 's proposal fragile and said its spending and deficit ceilings did not inspire confidence `` last year 's experience was not encouraging since spending exceeded its ceiling by more than 700 billion lebanese pounds 450 million and the planned 35 percent deficit of revenue against expenditure jumped to 51 percent '' moussawi said the 1996 deficit target was in fact 37.6 percent but the actual deficit reached 51 percent due to damage caused by a heavy israeli attack on lebanon in april and a slowdown of economic growth during the year however the deficit also overran government targets in 1994 and 1995 of 43 per cent and 44 percent reaching 57 percent and 47 percent respectively and accusations have intensified that the government routinely presents unrealistic budgets pro-government deputies dominate the 128-member parliament and it is expected to approve the budget on saturday despite the tough criticisms during the first two days of the debate the draft proposes expenditures of 6,433 billion pounds and revenues of 4,100 billion pounds -- a deficit of about 36 percent proposed spending is slightly lower than 1996 projections and planned revenue is slightly higher moussawi warned the government against increasing taxes to reduce the deficit referring to media reports of possible increases of petrol and electricity prices he said `` we warn that this could lead to a wide popular explosion '' he proposed instead the introduction of progressive taxation to replace the current 10 percent flat rate for income and corporate tax in another attack on the government hassan alawiyyeh a shi'ite moslem deputy told parliament lebanon 's indebtedness was reaching a dangerous level `` this budget depends mainly on domestic and foreign debt and debt figures have touched the red line threatening negative implications for future generations '' alawiyyeh said foreign and domestic debt have risen sharply in the past four years because much of lebanon 's multi-billion-dollar reconstruction drive is being carried out through foreign borrowing while the budget deficit is financed by heavy domestic borrowing foreign and net domestic debt have each more than doubled since december 1994 foreign debt has risen to 1.769 billion from 772 million and net domestic debt to 13,315 billion lebanese pounds from 6,682 billion total debt reached 10.348 billion at end of december 1996 a figure which according to one parliamentary deputy approaches lebanon 's estimated annual gross domestic french magistrates on friday welcomed president jacques chirac 's plans to bolster the independence of the judiciary but some questioned his determination to get to the heart of sleaze in french politics in a televised interview on thursday chirac said he wanted the centre-right cabinet to initiate radical reform aimed at making public prosecutors independent of the justice ministry the daily le monde said chirac had broken `` a very french judicial taboo '' with the idea of scrapping a system that makes prosecutors subordinate to the ministry -- and open to charges of political manipulation the government caused an outcry last month by chartering a helicopter in a vain attempt to track down a prosecutor trekking in the himalayas to discuss a probe opened by his zealous deputy against the wife of the mayor of paris justice minister jacques toubon said it had been necessary to check whether the probe did not contradict the prosecutor 's instructions ths scandal caused charges that the government was trying to block an embarrassing probe judges and magistrates generally welcomed the planned reform and said they would help the work of any commission set up toubon said the commission of legal experts perhaps led by the head of the supreme court would be set up in coming days but some experts worried chirac 's announcement was window-dressing at a time when all political parties including the rally for the republic rpr chirac founded in 1976 are increasingly targeted by political funding scandals `` we will ensure that the work is not buried '' said valery turcey head of the centrist union syndicale des magistrats welcoming the proposed reform he said the rpr was `` ringed on all sides by the multiplication of corruption cases '' the leftist syndicat de la magistrature also said chirac 's proposal was `` interesting '' the right-wing apm magistrates group close to toubon expressed concern that cutting the link between prosecutors and the ministry could create an italian-style system that it said would let prosecutors act with too little control at the same time as considering reform of the judicial hierarchy chirac said he wanted to strengthen the presumption of innocence until any suspect was proven guilty some magistrates feared this could muzzle investigators and the media making it easier to hush up politically-embarrassing cases chirac also said he wanted to reduce bureaucratic hurdles that make it too expensive to prosecute minor crimes

u.s. defence secretary william perry said on tuesday that predictions that a new military peacekeeping force would go to bosnia were `` premature '' and that washington would make no commitment for u.s. participation until all alternatives had been studied `` i think all such judgements are premature i really do '' perry told reporters of predictions by german defence minister volker ruehe and others that a new international force would be sent to bosnia next year to replace the current nato-led force of 55,000 troops to be withdrawn in december perry spoke to reporters aboard his aircraft as he arrived in bergen for a two-day meeting of nato defence ministers to begin discussing whether to extend the peacekeeping mission in bosnia `` in the last analysis they other countries will reserve their final judgement until they see what the military requests are '' perry added `` i do n't think we the united states can have a position until we see what the request is what the mission is what the force structure requested is '' he added

south african president nelson mandela has told members of his african national congress they will decide who succeeds him as party leader state radio said the south african broadcasting corporation quoted sources at a weekend meeting of the anc 's national executive committee as saying mandela told delegates he had not endorsed deputy president thabo mbeki to be the next party leader mandela 78 has previously described mbeki as the kind of person who could step into his shoes mandela plans to resign when general elections are held in 1999 `` mandela says democratic procedures will be followed in the election of both the anc leader and president of the country when he steps down '' the sabc said `` he says he will leave the issue of his successor as party leader to the anc congress which is to be held next year '' many political and economic commentators had in recent months taken it as read that mbeki would succeed mandela the anc could not immediately be reached for comment on the radio report an official party statement on the nec meeting made no mention of the succession

israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu weathered criticism at a likud party congress on thursday over his landmark meeting with plo head yasser arafat but he vowed to take a hard line in peace talks with the palestine liberation organisation plo which his party had refused to recognise until his meeting with arafat on wednesday after netanyahu threatened to fire ministers who did not toe his line on peace moves infrastructure minister ariel sharon and science minister binyamin begin the most hawkish members of his cabinet made clear they had no fear of being sacked netanyahu began his speech with a party-pleasing broadside at former prime minister shimon peres who he defeated in may elections in which he rejected the plo 's goal of a state and hailed jewish settlement of the west bank and gaza strip `` you can dream every night ... and you will still wake up every morning and see there is no palestinian state there is no palestinian state there is not and there will not be a palestinian state '' he said to applause `` and jewish settlement in judea and samaria the west bank will live will thrive will exist forever '' he added palestinians say settlement must stop in answer to a heckler from the audience netanyahu said `` yes yes also in the gaza strip in gush katif certainly '' gush katif is the name of a block of jewish settlements in the gaza strip the rest of which has been handed over to palestinian rule under interim peace deals cut by the previous government netanyahu added he had expressed his commitment to settlement in the meeting with arafat `` whoever comes with complaints now did n't have to join the coalition and did n't have to join the government ... there is only one prime minister '' netanyahu said earlier in an interview with israel television asked if he would fire ministers who did not fall into line with his policy netanyahu had said `` if necessary yes '' sharon long a champion of jewish settlement and who said on wednesday the arafat meeting was a mistake was not cowed by the threat making a veiled one of his own `` it is possible to replace a minister ... governments can also be replaced '' sharon who has in the past referred to arafat as a war criminal said in his speech the party convention scheduled before the arafat meeting to deal with internal matters was overshadowed by the handshake on wednesday between the right-wing israeli leader and plo chief `` i did everything so this man could betray me and my friends ... what right did he have to go and shake the hand of this killer of children '' one member of the hundreds-strong central committee screamed on israel radio but sentiments in the hall were mixed backers of the meeting like likud member of parliament meir sheetreet said netanyahu was pragmatic and would ensure that a deal satisfying right-wing principles would result from negotiations

england 's hopes of staging the 2006 world cup finals were boosted on thursday when uefa were forced to back down in a row over their support for germany uefa president lennart johannson said while european soccer 's governing body would not break a `` gentleman 's agreement '' they have had with germany since 1993 they accepted england 's bid would be decided upon along with germany 's by democratic process in due course `` i am delighted with what has happened today '' said english football association f.a chief executive graham kelly who together with german officials met uefa representatives to discuss the confusion surrounding the two bids the confusion arose because the germans believed they would be the only european country bidding to stage the finals and that a non-minuted `` gentleman 's agreement '' dating from 1993 would guarantee that situation english officials say they were never party to that and they had always intended to bid for the finals in the event of staging euro 96 successfully franz beckenbauer the former west german captain and coach who is now spearheading germany 's bid was disappointed with the outcome of thursday meetings the german f.a always believed england would not stand in the way of a german bid `` i believe the situation we now find ourselves in will divide the european bid and could be an advantage to a third country '' beckenbauer said a decision on who eventually hosts the finals will be taken by the executive committee of fifa world soccer 's governing body in three years time south africa brazil argentina egypt and morocco have already expressed an early interest in staging them

greek foreign minister theodoros pangalos joined a chorus of angry greek reaction against world athletics chief primo nebiolo on tuesday saying the italian lawyer was uninformed and should keep out of politics seen as an enemy of athens 's bid to host the 2004 olympics also sought by rome and three other cities nebiolo told greek television that the games will not solve greece 's political and economic problems `` mr. nebiolo committed a gross violation of a very basic rule '' the outspoken pangalos told reporters `` politicians are allowed to speak about sports but sports officials are not allowed to speak about politics '' the head of the international amateur athletic federation iaaf which held its world championship in athens last week prompted a fresh storm of reaction in greece after comments to the private mega television channel on monday evening `` you have many problems economic political ... problems with the maastricht treaty the value of money and unemployment and the olympic games will not solve these problems '' he told mega greek newspapers lashed out at nebiolo in front-page banner headlines calling him `` mafioso '' `` duce '' and a shameless advocate of rome 's bid to host the games rome and athens are the favourites among the five bidding cities especially after the explosion which on friday destroyed sections of the olympic stadium in stockholm the third european candidate cape town and buenos aires are the other bidding cities who learn their fate in lausanne on september 5 athens bid hinged on a well-run championships a nearly empty stadium on the first weekend was an embarrassment to organisers who blamed it on the long duration of the event and expensive tickets nebiolo was quick to criticise both greek organisers and the public his comments prompted a flurry of reaction and he was greeted with loud boos at the closing ceremony on sunday `` there has maybe not been a great campaign of promotion '' nebiolo had said `` maybe because it was saturday people in athens go to the sea ... they have the sea all year they can forget the sea for a week '' seats were promptly filled out and observers praised the event 's efficiency nebiolo told mega the success of the championships was mainly owed to iaaf and not greek organisers whom he described as `` mediocre '' athens mayor dimitris avramopoulos and greek olympic committee head lambis nicolaou accused nebiolo of painting greece as a troubled nation to promote rome 's olympic candidacy pangalos said that nebiolo was `` not well informed '' about greece and lashed back describing italy as a country that faces security problems because of the mafia `` italy uses its armed forces to deal with the terrifying problem of the mafia which it exports to the rest of the world like the united states and recently albania '' he said `` but i would never say that the mafia characterises italy and therefore rome does not deserve the games rome will not win the games simply because athens is better '' he added

afghanistan 's radical islamic taleban militia said on sunday it had driven opposition forces out of two districts in an overnight attack north of the afghan capital kabul taleban-controlled kabul radio said that taleban forces had cleared mir bachakot and guldara districts of forces loyal to ousted government commander ahmad shah masood and northern uzbek chief general abdul rashid dostum the sunday night broadcast monitored in islamabad said the northwards advance against `` evil forces '' was continuing there was no independent confirmation of the report the kabul broadcast said the deputy chief of the taleban ruling council in the capital mullah mohammad hasan akhund visited frontlines and quoted him as saying in mir bacha kot that taleban forces were fighting with a high morale earlier on sunday a pakistan-based afghan news service aip quoted taleban sources as saying the islamic militia had launched a successful attack on the northern alliance forces on a front that has been at stalemate for several weeks the afghan islamic press aip quoted the sources as saying in the southern afghan city of kandahar where the purist islamic taleban has its headquarters as saying that at least 24 fighters from both sides were killed or wounded the agency quoted the sources as saying taleban fighters had entered the village of kalakan 25 km 19 miles north of kabul that had been occupied by masood 's forces the taleban captured kabul on september 27 and then pushed north before being rolled back by a masood counter-offensive masood was then joined by dostum for the past few weeks the two sides have been fighting over a band of hills that runs part way across the shamali valley around kalakan attempts by the united nations and pakistan to forge a ceasefire that would lead to peace talks to end 17 years of civil war in afghanistan have so far come to nothing taleban officials in kabul said earlier saturday 's attack was launched along the so-called old road which runs up the western side of the broad valley that runs north from kabul throughout saturday night and sunday morning the sound of rocket and artillery fire was clearly audible in kabul itself some 20 km 13 miles from the scene of the fighting both sides were still exchanging heavy barrages of artillery and rockets on sunday morning taleban multi-barrelled rocket launchers were firing salvo after salvo of rockets towards the positions of the alliance forces while behind the front lines tank crews were cleaning shells in preparation for going up to the lines a steady trickle of families -- their possessions loaded on to donkeys and wheelbarrows -- moved south a shepherd who was also moving south with his livestock told reuters in kabul `` this is the heaviest fighting i have seen since the taleban were forced back in mid-october '' on the kabul front the taleban hold a strategic line of low hills that the alliance must capture if they are to launch an offensive against kabul itself the taleban have vowed to disarm other armed groups in afghanistan and impose their puritanical vision of islam on the whole country the taleban have agreed in principle to the necessity of a ceasefire but their demands are unlikely to be acceptable to their opposition

zaire 's army ambushed rebels advancing on the eastern town of kindu killing hundreds and forcing others to retreat eastwards the defence ministry said on wednesday a senior defence official told reuters the rebels were ambushed on tuesday night 35 km 22 miles from kindu at a road junction at the village of muyengo `` they were moving up the road calmly apparently expecting no resistance the zairean army ambushed them at the junction between two roads leading north to punia and west to kindu '' the official said `` there were hundreds killed and the rest were forced to retreat towards kalima in the early hours '' he added the official said that zairean army units were pursuing the rebels eastwards towards the town of kalima which the rebels took last weekend the rebels took up arms last october and seized towns and territory in the east they blunted a much-vaunted army counter-offensive by attacking on several fronts zaire accuses rwanda uganda and burundi of invading to fight alongside them all three deny the charge

france on wednesday stripped ex-businessman and soccer boss bernard tapie of his seat in the european parliament but his lawyers immediately appealed against the unprecedented decision a decree published in the official gazette and signed by prime minister alain juppe and the ministers for justice foreign affairs and european affairs said `` the ineligibility of mr bernard tapie puts an end to his mandates as a representative of the european parliament '' tapie 's lawyer frederic thiriez said such a decision by national authorities was unprecedented in the european parliament and he appealed to the council of state france 's highest administrative court to suspend it the decree was sent to the speaker of the strasbourg-based parliament and france 's envoy to the institution will officially notify the speaker 's office on thursday a parliamentary committee was due to meet later this week to rule on the decree it has the power to overturn the decision but french officials said this was unlikely tapie has already been ejected from the french national assembly lower house under a court ruling upheld by the supreme court declaring him to be bankrupt and ineligible for public office french authorities say he must give up his european seat for the same reason they say that under european union law individual member states determine eligibility for the european parliament thiriez said it would take a few weeks for the counciul of state to rule on tapie 's appeal tapie 's lawyers have already appealed to the european court of human rights that depriving him of his seat was contrary to the european convention of human rights the strasbourg-based court usually takes several years to deliver rulings tapie the target of a blizzard of legal actions over his now-destroyed business empire and the marseille soccer team he once ran has been sentenced to jail terms of eight and six months for tax fraud and rigging a soccer match he is appealing in both cases to the supreme court

mexico on sunday named a veteran politician as peace negotiator with zapatista indian rebels in southern chiapas state officials said pedro joaquin coldwell a former minister of tourism in the early 1990s was tapped by president ernesto zedillo to head the government delegation to the talks which broke down earlier this year on issues of indian autonomy coldwell 47 replaces marco antonio bernal a ruling party politician who is running for a senate seat in upcoming mid-term elections in july coldwell was also a former governor of quintana roo state in the 1980s and secretary general of the ruling institutional revolutionary party according to state-owned news agency notimex the zapatista guerrillas took up arms in january 1994 to demand greater democracy and rights for the region 's impoverished indians at least 150 people died in two weeks of fighting but a ceasefire has since held while both sides have tried to reach a final peace accord the zapatistas charismatic leader subcommander marcos broke off talks in january when the government tried to revise an agreement on indian rights reached between the rebels and a legislative government commission zedillo also named alejandro carrillo castro 56 as the government 's chief spokesman carrillo worked in the finance ministry in the 1970s notimex said

the damage from a political scandal depends on a how weighty the allegations are and b how long it lasts our concern is not what the government should or should not have done in the woods affair rather the question is how does this affect the administration 's standing with voters the answer is probably not much although the outcomes of these things are extremely difficult to predict the scandal contains two allegations that might damage the government firstly a very junior member of the government the parliamentary secretary for health is being investigated for fiddling his expenses an allegation he denies the investigation itself may repel some voters -- and of course we have no firm way to calculate how many -- and if woods is subsequently prosecuted and convicted then the government might lose a little more support note however that he would be a former senator by the time of any prosecution and that would mitigate the loss secondly the opposition asserts that prime minister john howard has tried to keep the investigation under wraps and moreover misled the public when he failed to admit on television he had known about it for months howard said he could not publicise the investigation since that would tip-off woods as to the other accusation -- misleading the public -- he says he simply forgot the opposition might say this is an unsatisfactory response and if so it might damage the government 's support a little but it is difficult to see where the affair goes from here if the opposition can not come up with new developments to feed the media 's need for a fresh angle then the story connecting woods with howard disappears often a scandal damages a government not because of the original unattractive event -- in this case the alleged expenses-fiddling -- but because of subsequent attempts to cover it up which tend to keep it going former health minister carmen lawrence 's easton affair comes to mind perth solicitor penny easton killed herself after lawrence 's western australian state government targetted her in parliament lawrence suffered prolonged political damage in 1995 not because of her association with the suicide but because she denied knowing about it an inquiry found that she did know about it and so the opposition could call her a liar in this case it is difficult to see what further progress the opposition can make in accusing the government of a cover-up -- canberra bureau 61-6 273-2730

king hussein of jordan said on thursday `` the impossible '' had to be done to halt two days of bloody clashes between palestinians and israeli soldiers `` we have to do the impossible to calm matters to stop them from worsening '' the state-run news agency petra quoted him as saying at the airport after returning from qatar earlier in the day he said israel must be stopped from continuing work on a tunnel in jerusalem near islam 's third holiest mosque and an international committee should be set up to deal with the issue thirty-three palestinians and 10 israelis have been killed in two days of clashes in the gaza strip and west bank sparked by the opening of the tunnel `` in my opinion an international committee should be formed to discuss what happened and how it happened at al-aqsa mosque '' he told a news conference in the qatari capital doha after talks with the emir sheikh hamad bin khalifa al-thani `` this committee should consist of representatives of all international organisations ... israel must be stopped from going ahead with the tunnel '' he added `` jerusalem must be a symbol of peace '' `` i believe there is still hope for peace everyone has suffered so much it will be a disaster for all of us if we move away from the peace process '' king hussein added jordan 's peace treaty with israel signed in 1994 recognised jordan 's `` special role '' in moslem holy shrines in arab jerusalem jordan which ruled the west bank and arab jerusalem from 1952 until losing it to israel in 1967 remains the legal guardian of the christian and holy places in the divided city -- a thorn in ties with the plo the official qatari news agency had earlier said that king hussein and qatar 's emir condemned israel 's opening of the tunnel and held it responsible for the clashes it said the two leaders said the tunnel was `` a violation of the sanctity of the holy city and a provocation of the arab and moslem feelings and contradicts the principles of the peace accord '' the israeli move has sparked the bloodiest clashes in the west bank since palestinian self rule began two years ago israel says that opening a second entrance to the tunnel beside the dome of the rock and al-aqsa mosque complex makes an important archaeological site more accessible to tourists

central african republic 's president named outgoing foreign minister michel gbezzera-bria on thursday to head a national unity government to end a cycle of military political and ethnic violence in the country president ange-felix patasse nominated gbezzera-bria 51 a career administrator in a decree that follows a january 25 peace deal brokered by african mediators to end the impoverished nation 's third army mutiny in under a year a former ambassador to the united nation and foreign minister in the outgoing government gbezzera-bria would form and head a `` government of action for the defence of democracy '' the decree said he replaces jean-paul ngoumpande who was nominated in june 1996 in an earlier gesture of national reconciliation the paramilitary gendarmerie on tuesday freed 35 people detained by french soldiers during violent incidents on january 4 and 5 they included seven mutineers mutinies in april and may began over pay and conditions but turned into a campaign to oust patasse a northern civilian who won presidential elections in 1993 the latest mutiny which began on november 15 degenerated into ethnic feuding the mutineers were from the minority yakoma tribe of former military leader andre kolingba estimates of those killed in the mutinies range from scores to several hundred french troops in the country under a defence pact stepped in to restore order the presidents of gabon chad mali and burkina faso launched the mediation process in december at the behest of a franco-african summit mali 's widely respected former military leader amadou toumani toure brokered the deal the peace blueprint also envisaged amnesties restoration of constitutional legality under the democratic transition and a 500-strong african peacekeeping force with soldiers from burkina faso chad gabon mali senegal and togo

indian prime minister h.d deve gowda will visit moscow next week for talks with russian president boris yeltsin including an exchange of views on afghanistan a spokesman said on thursday the two leaders will also review the proposed sale of russian nuclear reactors to india a deal the united states wants moscow to scrap he said diplomatic sources said the visit could also result in a meeting between foreign minister inder gujral a member of the indian team on the four-day visit starting on monday and his chinese counterpart qian qichen due in moscow at the same time gujral told reuters on wednesday he had no immediate plans to meet qian in moscow `` but i would definitely like to meet my colleague if there is an opportunity '' the indian and chinese ministers are expected to be briefed by russian officials on yeltsin 's summit with u.s. president bill clinton beginning in helsinki on thursday diplomats said both countries share russia 's opposition to nato 's expansion plans in eastern europe `` on afghanistan we share russia 's concerns on the rising tide of religious fundamentalism '' an indian foreign ministry official told reuters `` we believe the rise of islamic taleban in afghanistan has also upset the central asian countries '' asked if moscow planned to call off the nuclear reactors offer to india following u.s. pressure the indian spokesman said `` our understanding is that russia does not allow third parties to influence its decisions in such matters '' the new york times quoted u.s. officials last month as opposing the planned sale of two light-water nuclear reactors to india saying it violated an international agreement the newspaper quoted an unidentified senior u.s. official as saying the sale would be a setback for worldwide efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons the official also said the `` russian federation as signatories to the 1992 suppliers agreement should not be selling these controlled nuclear technologies '' the suppliers agreement forbids suppliers from exporting nuclear technology to aspiring nuclear powers sales are forbidden to countries not formally recognised as nuclear weapons states and which do not allow international inspections of key nuclear institutes only the u.s. russia britain france and china are recognised nuclear weapons states russian officials insisted the sale to india should be exempt from the agreement because it was included in an earlier understanding between then-president mikhail gorbachev and indian leaders the initial agreement to build the reactors was reached in 1987 russian officials say the value of the sale to india was 1.5 billion to 2 billion for each of the light-water reactors india exploded an atomic device in 1974 but says its atomic programme is peaceful

britain said on wednesday it was ready to keep 5,000 heavily-armed ground troops in bosnia next year as part of an international peacekeeping force the ministry of defence said the troops would be part of a `` follow on '' force expected to replace the current nato-led peace force whose mandate expires at the end of next month the new british force would be equipped with challenger tanks scimitar armoured reconnaissance vehicles track mounted artillery and warrior armoured fighting vehicles a ministry spokesman said these ground forces would be backed up in the air by harrier tornado and jaguar combat aircraft the spokesman said the commitment of forces by defence secretary michael portillo depended on what nato planners ultimately decided would be necessary and the readiness of other nations to contribute to the new peacekeeping force britain which currently has around 8,000 troops in bosnia as part of the 55,000-strong ifor force hosts an international conference on the civilian aspects of peace implementation in bosnia on wednesday and thursday of next week

iran denied on monday that a statement by iranian foreign minister ali akbar velayati meant tehran was willing to engage in dialogue with washington iranian foreign ministry spokesman mahmoud mohammadi quoted by tehran radio said velayati 's statement `` had nothing to do with an exchange of letters with the aim of setting up a dialogue between iran and america '' velayati told reporters on sunday iran was ready to answer messages sent by the united states through the u.s. official interests section in tehran mohammadi said velayati was answering a question about whether iran had received a `` threatening letter '' from the united states `` velayati ... denied this claim and said that the islamic republic of iran was an independent country which would give a clear answer based on the honour of iran 's revolutionary nation to any threatening letter '' mohammadi was quoted as saying `` iran 's position is the same stance that has been expressed by the honourable leader ayatollah ali khamenei ... which is also what mr. velayati has said '' he added khamenei two weeks ago rejected suggestions that talks could be held with washington he was apparently referring to a call by u.s. assistant secretary of state robert pelletreau for talks with tehran on bilateral differences an iranian newspaper has carried a report saying tehran received a threatening letter from washington over iran 's opposition to the u.s.-sponsored middle east peace process the united states imposed a trade and investment ban on iran in june 1995 accusing it of sponsoring terrorism and seeking to develop nuclear weapons iran denies the charges and says the united states seeks to destroy the islamic government washington stepped up its campaign in august with a new law that tightened the sanctions by including non-u.s. firms which invest 40 million or more in iran 's vital oil and gas industry washington broke diplomatic ties with tehran in 1980 after moslem militants seized the u.s. embassy there holding 52 americans hostage for 444 days in the wake of the islamic revolution that toppled the late shah a close u.s. ally

seven maoist guerrillas were killed in a shoot-out with police on friday in the southern indian state of andhra pradesh police said the shoot-out between the guerrillas of the outlawed people 's war group pwg and the police took place near the laxmapur forest about 70 km 44 miles from hyderabad the state capital in another incident the maoist guerrillas shot dead a political worker of the ruling telugu desam party in nizamabad district of the state the press trust of india news agency said the pwg is one of many maoist rebel groups considered part of the naxalite movement which started in india in the 1960s among groups which split from the main communist party it was first banned in andhra pradesh in 1992 but gained a year-long reprieve beginning in june 1995 before being banned again in july last year

more than 400 french troops boarded a ship on thursday ready to leave for albania the first part of a 1,000-strong french contingent in an italian-led force to the battered state the troops boarded the 150-metre long orage landing ship in the mediterranean port of toulon and were awaiting a formal green light from rome to depart on friday the remaining 600 or so would travel by a specially-chartered ferry `` a meeting is going on in rome right now at which the final details of the intervention will be worked out '' a defence ministry official said the french troops part of a u.n.-approved force of up to 6,000 soldiers aim to disembark at the northern port of durres and secure the road to tirana about 40 km 25 miles east for supplies of food and medicines the french contingent includes wheeled tanks armoured personnel carriers and two puma transport helicopters all units have experience of foreign missions notably in former yugoslavia the french force should be completely operational 13 days after disembarcation in albania where anger at failed savings schemes this year spilled over into an armed insurrection the security force is due to begin arriving in albania on monday italy is planning to send about 2,000 soldiers greece 600 spain 300 turkey 600 and romania 300

rescuers recovered 24 bodies by daybreak on tuesday from a packed train ripped by a bomb planted by suspected separatist guerrillas in northeastern india and officials said the toll could rise sharply three of the train 's 15 carriages -- each crammed with 75 to 100 people going off on holiday -- were destroyed in the blast after the train left kokrajhar station in assam state for delhi around 7 p.m. 1330 gmt on monday police said soon after the explosion a senior police officer in assam 's capital guwahati said at least 300 people were believed dead but darkness and the remoteness of the region hampered rescuers and compounded confusion over the number of dead and wounded as day broke 24 bodies including those of 10 children had been found in the mangled wreckage `` they have recovered 24 dead and 63 injured '' a police official in guwahati told reuters by telephone quoting rescuers at the site of the blast in sensapani 200 km 125 miles west of the state capital he said it would not be clear until later in the day whether at least 300 people had died as police earlier said asked if the death toll was expected to rise the official said `` it could rescue and recovery operations are on they are looking for more dead bodies '' asked if authorities would confirm the earlier estimate of at least 300 dead the police official said `` it is guesswork '' there was no
